metadata.title: Environmental friendly synthesis of TiO2-ZnO nanocomposite catalyst and silver nanomaterials for the enhanced production of biodiesel from Ulva lactuca seaweed and potential antimicrobial properties against the microbial pathogens

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Photochemistry & Photobiology, B: Biology
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jphotobiol
Environmental friendly synthesis of TiO2-ZnO nanocomposite catalyst and silver nanomaterials for the enhanced production of biodiesel from Ulva lactuca seaweed and potential antimicrobial properties against the microbial pathogens Sivaprakash Gurusamya, Mohan Rasu Kulanthaisamya,b, Dinesh Gujuluva Haria,b, Ananthi Veleeswaranb,c, Boobalan Thulasinathanb, Jothi Basu Muthuramalingamd, Ravindran Balasubramanie,⁎, Soon Woong Change, Mariadhas Valan Arasuf, Naif Abdullah Al-Dhabif, Arokiyaraj Selvarajg, Arun Alagarsamyb,⁎
a Department of Energy Science, Alagappa University, Karaikudi, India bDepartment of Microbiology, Alagappa University, Karaikudi, India c Department of Zoology and Microbiology, Thiagarajar College, Madurai, India dDepartment of Botany, DDE, Alagappa University, Karaikudi, India e Department of Environmental Energy and Engineering, Kyonggi University, Youngtong – Gu, Suwon 16227, Republic of Korea fDepartment of Botany and Microbiology, College of Sciences, King Saud University, Saudi Arabia g Department of Food Science and Biotechnology, Sejong University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: TiO2–ZnO nanocomposites Ulva lactuca Algal biodiesel Silver nanoparticles Antibacterial activity
A B S T R A C T
TiO2-ZnO heterogeneous catalytic system provides a good replacement of a homogeneous catalytic reaction due to its easier recovery. In this study, biodiesel was produced from Ulva lactuca seaweeds using TiO2–ZnO nanocomposite catalysts with particle size of ~12 nm. The size controlled TiO2–ZnO nanocomposite was characterized by powder XRD analysis and TEM. The result of that TiO2–ZnO catalyst is a promising catalyst for the production of biodiesel under mild reaction conditions and high yield of hydroxydecanoic acid conversion of 82.8%. The various conditions optimized for the higher conversion to FAME (15.8ml of FAME) were 4 wt% catalysts at 4 h under 60 °C and further there is no increase of conversion to FAME above 60 °C–80 °C. The total product yield was calculated as 82.8% of conversion to FAME. The evaluated biodiesel was found to be up to the mark of ASTM standards. The silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) were synthesized by using leftover biomass of algae obtaining after lipid extraction of U.lactuca. AgNPs particle size was achieved as ~12 nm and was confirmed by UV–Visible spectroscopy, XRD and TEM analysis. Antibacterial activities of the synthesized AgNPs were analyzed and compared. The antibacterial activity was excellent against bacterial pathogens and treatment against P. vulgaris shows the maximum zone of inhibition (13.8mm). The present work identified that the unutilized bioresource such as U.lactuca can be effectively utilized for biodiesel production so as to replace fossil fuel usage.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The energy crisis in India is due to the excessive dependency only on fossil fuel and thereby creates energy scarcity [1]. As the fossil fuel energy resource in India is limited and lack of adaptability for alternative energy policy, it depends on other countries for energy resources. The excessive use of energy will ultimately exhaust fossil fuel resources [2], raise carbon dioxide emission in turn increases the green house effect that is hazardous for the environment, thus demands the
development of sustainable energy sources [3]. Potential of biofuels provides energy demands for significant portion of our society's [4]. The production of biodiesel were carried out by various sources such as plants, rapeseed, soybean, sunflower, microalgae, palm, animal fat and were used as an alternative energy sources [5–7]. Algal biomass have large productivity potential, which do not compete for agricultural land, able to withstand different temperature, nutrient concentrations, salinity and farming practices [8]. The numerous researches were focused on microalgae, moreover several species consists of nearly 30%
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jphotobiol.2019.02.011 Received 27 January 2019; Received in revised form 20 February 2019; Accepted 26 February 2019
⁎ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: kalamravi@gmail.com (R. Balasubramani), arunalacha@gmail.com (A. Alagarsamy).
Journal of Photochemistry & Photobiology, B: Biology 193 (2019) 118–130
Available online 27 February 2019 1011-1344/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
lipid on dry weight [9–11]. Notably, some major challenges in microalgae are harvesting and cultivation which leads concern towards seaweeds [12–14]. Seaweeds are having commercially important lipid consisting polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) [15], protein, fatty acid contents in higher level, which are biological components with interesting functional properties [16], were commercialized for biomedical, pharmaceutical, nutraceutical properties and about 2400 natural products were reported [17]. Consumption of fuel feedstock such as marine macroalgal species achieves a maximum growth rate comparing terrestrial and water grown biomass [18]. Currently, algal resources have being practiced with interest as an alternative resource of renewable energy feedstock in across the world [19]. Bruhn et al. [20] highlighted the successful usage of Ulva for better growing and biomass producing macro algae in open ocean culture.
U. lactuca seaweed is not used as human food and having 8.5% of lipid [21], moreover it is abundant, not commercially exploited, and are available at the eastern seashore of the Nambuthalai coastal area of India, so the present work aimed to use U. lactuca for the production of biodiesel and silver nanoparticles.
Methyl ester production by using basic catalytic methodologies may yield FAME (Fatty acid methyl ester) [22–24]. Lipids can be transesterified from various biological sources in the presence of homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts. Product quality and synthesis conditions were improved while using nanocomposites as catalysts [22]. Effective biodiesel transesterification can be achieved by heterogeneous metal oxide catalysts than the usage of homogeneous catalyst [23]. Generally mixed metal oxide nanoparticles has well known surface acidity which acts as a solid catalyst provides higher prolonged catalytic activity in the transesterification process [24]. Heterogeneous TiO2–ZnO nanocomposite catalysts provide higher activity, selectivity, water tolerance properties [25], easier catalytic separation, pollution reduction, low reaction temperature and time. Requiting affordable, selective and stable catalysts occurs a impact in the production process [26]. Divalent metal oxides provide a considerable covalent character which enhances transesterification [25]. ZnO is an amphoteric oxide having capability of transesterifying Free Fatty Acid (FFA) oil at both acid and base sites [27]. In transesterification, high density material like ZnO on TiO2 leads to increase accessibility on FFA, methanol and triglycerides [28]. And particular TiO2 has broad spectrum and attracts with excellent applications gas sensors, medicine, catalyst support, pigments, cosmetics and solar cells, antibacterial, environmental remediation, air purification, water disinfection [28–32]. Optimization was carried out to determine amount of catalyst, oil molar ratio, temperature, and time [33,34]. At present there are no reports that utilized TiO2–ZnO from seaweed lipid. TiO2–ZnO mixed oxide nanocomposite as catalyst for
transesterification process was effectively used in transesterification of palm oil into FAME based on glycerol nitrate combustion method [35]. Subramani et al., [36] derived Mn3O4 nanocubes from decomposition of metal hexocyanoferrate by using simple co-precipitation method for super capacitor application. This method is ecofriendly, low cost, less energy consuming, less time consuming and suitable for large-scale synthesis of metal oxide nanoparticles. Superior advantages attracted towards the method used by Subramani et al., [36] with other heterogeneous catalyst synthesis methods [35]. The basic lipid extraction techniques were not applicable to attain complete extraction. So it needs formic acid, hydrochloric acids for rupturing tissues, ethanol and chloroform for extracting the solvent [21]. In the present study, TiO2–ZnO nanocatalyst was produced by co-precipitation method and optimization was established using the laboratory scale biodiesel production parameters such as catalyst concentration, temperature and reaction time during transesterification process [33,37].
Due to the broad spectrum and large surface area nanoscale silver nanoparticles were highlighted as a potential candidate against multiresistant microbes [38,39]. Increasing market prices, safe development, environmental friendly approaches for biogenic production is now in more interest due to the simplicity of the procedures and versatility [38]. Currently, there is a increasing necessitate to develop environmental friendly and sustainable methods for the synthesis of
nanomaterials without utilizing harmful chemicals in the synthesis protocols, which curtail negative impacts in medical application [40]. The exact reaction mechanism leading to the formation of AgNPs is yet to be elucidated [41] but it is believed that natural products are having
the rich amount of alkaloids and flavonoids, consisting large amount of electrons and these electrons were reducing the silver nitrate into AgNPs. In antibacterial activity of AgNPs, the most believed mechanism is interaction between bacterial cell membrane and surface interchange, which cause intercellular leakage leads to cell death [42]. Moreover, Ag+binds to the bacterial cell wall, it inhibits metabolic pathway by which leads to produce reactive oxygen species finally damaging the cells and destroying the DNA replication [43–45]. Considering the importance of silver nanoparticles in the medical field for developing toxic free nanoparticles from biosynthesis, we focused on the economical and effective production of AgNPs using leftover biomass obtained after lipid extraction from U. lactuca.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals
sections.text: All the chemicals such as Methanol, chloroform, hydrochloric acid, Sodium hydroxide were purchased in highest purity available from Himedia, India. Titanium (IV) oxysulfate with maximum purity of ≥29% was obtained from Sigma Aldrich, India.

sections.heading: 2.2. Collection and Processing of U. lactuca Seaweed
sections.text: U. lactuca seaweed samples were collected from the Nambuthalai coastal area of southeastern India (latitude: 9°43′21.43"N longitude: 79° 0'24.93"E). Samples were collected from tightly closed sterile container and were immediately carried to the laboratory then cleaned carefully several times in seawater to remove the unwanted epiphytes, sand, salt and other debris materials. The samples were collected in a sterile plastic bag and immediately transported to the laboratory for further usage. In the lab, the collected samples were washed several times with tap water and finally washed with double distilled water (DDW). After washing, the samples were dried under shade at room temperature. The dried samples were ground into fine particles using mixer grinder and stored in a glass container at room temperature for further usage.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of TiO2-ZnO Nanocatalyst
sections.text:
Subramani et al. [30] applied a simple co-precipitation technique for the synthesis of Mn3O4. In this work is used feasible method for the synthesis of TiO2-ZnO catalyst to be used for biodiesel production. The

entire process was carried out in the magnetic stirrer at 400 rpm speed. 0.159 g of titanium (IV) oxysulfate dissolved in 100ml of DDW was taken in glass beaker, 0.136 g of zinc chloride dissolved in 100ml DDW was added drop by drop on titanium (IV) oxysulfate solution to achieve 1:1 ratio of 10mM concentration. 20mM concentration of potassium ferricyanide (0.658 g in 100ml DDW) was added drop by drop on the mixer to form hexocyanoferrate complex. Titanium zinc mixed hexocyanoferrate (Ti-ZnHCF) was decomposed to TiO2–ZnO nanocubes by adding 4 g NaOH dissolved in 100ml DDW to achieve 1M NaOH concentration. The above mixture was stirred continuously at 400 rpm for 5 h at room temperature. Then the reduced sample was filtrated and washed several times with hot DDW for neutralizing the filtrate. The sample was dried, stored for characterization and transesterification process studies.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterization of TiO2-ZnO Nanocatalyst
sections.text:
The X-ray diffraction patterns of the TiO2-ZnO nanocatalyst was analyzed by using X'Pert Pro analytical diffractometer, Japan, using monochromatic nickel-filtered Cu Ka radiation (k=0.15405 nm). FTIR, TEM and EDAX were analyzed by following the standard
methodology.

sections.heading: 2.5. Extraction of Lipid from U. lactuca
sections.text:
The Lipid content of U. lactuca was extracted based on the protocol described in Yaich et al., [21] method. The extracted lipid was expressed as the percentage of lipid present in the wet matter of the algal powder. The algal oil molecular weight (g/mol) was calculated by following Eq. (1) [46].
= × × +MW 3 (MW %m ) 38oil i i i (1)
The remaining debris (other than lipid) was used for AgNPs synthesis.

sections.heading: 2.6. Conversion to FAME by Utilizing U. lactuca Lipid
sections.text:
Transesterification of the extracted lipid content was carried out in 3-necked round-bottom flask. The flask was placed in water bath over magnetic stirrer. Middle neck of the round bottom flask was inserted with thermometer, side neck was fitted with a condenser and the other side neck was used as port for adding catalyst. 25ml of algal oil with methanol (6:1 oil molar ratio) [47]with different percentage of catalysts (2, 4, 6, 8 and 10wt%) [33] were used for optimization of catalytic activity at different reaction temperature (40 °C–80 °C) and time (3 to 6 h) [48]. The total yield was calculated by using Eq. (2) [49].
= ×Weight of the product Weight of the raw material Product yield (%) 100 (2)
After transesterification the used catalyst was washed with methanol, 5M NH4OH solution and reused five times for the further transesterification process.

sections.heading: 2.7. Characterization of FAME
sections.text: Fatty acid methyl ester composition was evaluated by Gas Chromatography Mass Spectroscopy [46], including density (D1298), Acid value (D664), Sulfated ash [50], Iodine value, Water content, Density and Methanol content European Biodiesel Standards [51].

sections.heading: 2.8. Synthesis of AgNPs Using U. lactuca
sections.text: AgNPs were synthesized by using seaweed samples obtained after extraction of lipid from U. lactuca. Seaweed extracts were prepared by boiling 8 g of seaweed samples in 100ml of DDW at 80 °C for 20min. The different volume (1, 3 and 5ml) of filtered extracts was added on 1mM silver nitrate. AgNO3 solution and seaweed extracts were treated as control along with the experimental conditions. The reaction solutions were allowed to stir for 2 h at room temperature and the color changes from pale yellow to brown color indicates the presence of AgNPs.

sections.heading: 2.9. Characterization of AgNPs
sections.text: The bio reduction of AgNO3 into AgNPs was confirmed by UV–Visible spectroscopy (Shimadzu, Japan) in a range between 350 and 600 nm. The sample, which shows the highest observation peak value in UV–Visible spectra, was applied for further studies, its X-ray diffraction pattern was observed after drying the selected liquid samples using hot air oven at 100 °C for 5 h.

sections.heading: 2.10. Antibacterial Assay
sections.text:
Antibacterial activity of biosynthesized AgNPs (15 μg/ml) in deionised water was analyzed by agar well diffusion method [52]. Activity was analyzed against human pathogens such as Klebsiella pneumonia,
Bacillus subtilis, Proteus vulgaris and multi drug resistant pathogen Staphylococcus aureus. 24 h grown selected bacterial pathogenic broth suspensions were individually swabbed (using sterile cotton swabs) on sterile Muller Hinton Agar (MHA) under aseptic condition. Using sterile stainless steel well cutter, wells were made on MHA plates and were added with different volumes (25, 50 and 100 μl) of AgNPs (15 μl/ml concentration). The plates were incubated at 37 °C for 24 h. The activity of the AgNPs against the bacterial pathogens was compared with standard antibiotics (Tetracycline, Ampicillin, Clindamycin, Gentamicin, Teicoplanin, Vancomycin, Erythromycin and penicillin).

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of Synthesized TiO2-ZnO Nanocomposite
sections.text:
In order to identify the crystalline phase of TiO2-ZnO nanocomposite in the catalyst, we used X-ray diffraction for characterization [28].
Fig. 1 reveals the XRD patterns of metal oxides, mixed metal oxide such as TiO2, ZnO and TiO2–ZnO nanocomposite prepared by co-precipitation method. The XRD patterns suggested in Fig. 1a and b were good agreement with the standard ICDD No: 01–079-0208 for Hexagonal ZnO crystal and ICDD No: 01-084-1750 for the orthorhombic TiO2 system. Fig. 1c exposes both TiO2 and ZnO phases; it clearly indicates the formation of TiO2-ZnO nanocomposite. The broad and high
intensity peak of tiny particles confirms the amorphous nature of TiO2ZnO nanocomposite with particle size of 12 nm. TiO2 and ZnO with particle size of 11 nm and 10 nm respectively was estimated based on the diffraction reflection by using Debye–Scherrer equation Eq. (3) [53].
=D cos0.9 / (3)
Where D is the crystalline size, k is the incident X-ray wavelength, b is the full width at half maximum and h is the diffraction angle. The particle size produced in the present study is much smaller (12 nm) than the particle produced by glycerol-nitrate combustion method [35,54]. The FT-IR spectra of TiO2–ZnO mixed oxide nanocomposite was taken in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. Ti-O-Ti stretching vibration was confirmed by the corresponding bands at 664 and 1400 cm−1 [55], While the one found at 1658 cm−1 is equivalent to bending vibration of the H2O and Ti-OH, the peak at 609 cm−1 is due to the presence of ZnO and peak at 460 cm−1 indicates the ZneO vibration [28,55].
Fig. 2 shows a typical TEM image of TiO2-ZnO nanocomposite material which is completely rolled with TiO2 and ZnO like a sandwich. Similarly, TEM image revealed the high magnification of TiO2-ZnO nanocomposite. The SAED pattern of TiO2-ZnO shows that polycrystalline material was present. The EDAX study (Fig. 3) confirms that the nanocomposite is composed of Ti, Zn, Cu and O. The Synthesized TiO2-ZnO catalyst can esterify Free fatty acids from non utilized raw materials and non hazardous material. Moreover it yields successive results until the fourth usage which justify itself as a ecofriendly material [28].

sections.heading: 3.2. Analysis of Conversion to FAME Utilizing U. lactuca Lipid
sections.text:
In U. lactuca wet algal powder; we were able to achieved lipid extraction of about 8.5%. Yaich et al., [21] obtained 7.9% of lipid from U. lactuca. In the present study, U. lactuca originated from India shown to have same high level of lipid content. In order to find a higher conversion to FAME, different percentages of catalysts (2, 4, 6, 8 and 10wt %) at different reaction temperature (40 °C–80 °C) and time (3–6 h) were tested with constant methanol to oil molar ratio of 6:1. The various conditions optimized for the higher conversion to FAME (15.8ml of FAME) were 4 wt% catalysts at 4 h under 60 °C and further there is no increase of conversion to FAME above 60 °C–80 °C. The role of optimization of oil molar ratio in the reaction is highest mass ratio creates impacts in the methanol and oil molecules so the methyl ester increases methanol to oil mass ratio [56]. Its mandatory to identify the optimized reaction temperature because the temperature must to less than the alcohols boiling point and reaction time was optimized due to identify the relationship between the reaction temperature, time.
The total product yield was calculated as 82.8% of conversion to FAME. The same reaction parameters were applied in Mahula oil and they got the related results [33]. Here we have taken unutilized seaweed sample and got better result. Madhuvilakku and Piraman [35]
also proved that applying heterogeneous TiO2-ZnO catalyst, achieved a faster reaction rate until 4 h of reaction time. The reusability of the recollected catalyst was accessed and was found to be 100% activity for 3 cycles, later on the activity declined. The conversion of fatty acid methyl ester from U. lactuca algal oil was evaluated by Gas chromatography-Mass Spectroscopy analysis. The extracted lipid dry weight consists of different lipid components, because basically plant and algal species bears some nonpolar triacylglycerols containing fatty acids with phospholipids, sterols and vitamins [57].
The FTIR analysis (Fig. 4) was conducted in the mid infrared region to found the functional group, various bending and stretching frequencies of corresponding bands regarding to biodiesel blends [58]. FTIR was characterized on symmetric, asymmetric regions, it shown strong stretching vibrations of alkyl groups on 3404, 2648, 2381, 1411, ester group on 1708 cm−1 and it has been found as typical ester. Moreover alkane group was found at 1220 cm−1. The product obtained from the transesterification was confirmed as biodiesel [35,55].
From the algal oil fatty acid profile by comparing with standard data in GC MS software, we found that saturated fatty acids and poly unsaturated fatty acids (78.2%). Relative quantity of monounsaturated fatty acid profile was found between green algal species [59]. Concentration of oleic acid, octadecenoic was higher in green algae [59]. GC–MS result (Fig. 5) (Table 1) shows the presence of large amounts of saturated and monounsaturated fatty acids.
The other parameters of produced biodiesel was shown in Table 2, they were in accordance with ASTM standards. Some parameters are not found in ASTM standard methods. So we did European Biodiesel Standards for those parameters.
Density of biodiesel was slightly high (0.86%/ml) in our study than the normal diesel (0.83%/ml) [46].
Catalyst was reused twice as it provides a good catalytic activity and yields same conversion to FAME rate. The occurrence of large amounts of saturated and monounsaturated fatty acid shows the good performance of biodiesel conversion from U. lactuca. Excess amount of methanol was added to the above mixture in between the process of transesterification reaction for enhancing the reaction [60,61].

sections.heading: 3.3. Characterization of AgNPs
sections.text:
Silver nitrate ions reacted with U. lactuca extract. Difference in absorbance or wavelength indicated the interparticle properties and size, shape of the nanoparticles. Synthesis mechanism is a major key factor which determines the size of AgNPs [62]. The AgNPs absorption spectra of surface plasmon resonance were recorded at 400–450 nm, which recognized to AgNPs in several studies [45,63].
Ag-NPs show brownish color in aqueous state because of surface plasmon vibration in silver ions. So the reduction of sliver ions to nanoparticles could be followed by the color differences from the pale yellow to brownish color which was periodically stated by UV–Vis spectroscopy [64]. UV visible spectra of AgNPs from different volumes
Table 2 Physical property of extracted oil and biodiesel from U. lactuca.
Parameters Extracted algal oil Test method Units
Average molecular weight 780 ± 0.03 – g/mol Saponification value 180 ± 0.23 – ml of H3PO4 /g Flash point – D 93 °C Acid value 12 ± 0.06 D 664 ml of H3PO4/g Viscosity 5.2 ± 0.05 D 445 (mm2/s, at 313 K) Water content 3.6 ± 0.07 D 2709 %/ml Sulphated ash 0.006 ± 0.10 D 874 %/ml Iodine value 90 ± 0.09 EN 14111 – Water content 3.6 ± 0.10 EN ISO 12937 %/ml Density 0.86 ± 0.12 EN ISO 3675, EN ISO 12185 %/ml Methanol content 0.02 ± 0.03 EN 14110 % (mol/mol)
of U. lactuca extract (1, 3 and 5ml) were recorded (Fig. 6) at 440 nm. Fig. 7 shows the XRD pattern of AgNPs synthesized using U. lactuca. AgNPs exhibits strong peaks at 435 nm from 5ml of U.lactuca extract. Therefore, AgNPs synthesized from 5ml extract were used further for antibacterial studies. The TEM micrographs of AgNPs synthesized using U. lactuca (Fig. 8) confirms that silver nanoparticles were spherical is shape with an average size of.
~24 nm. From the results of XRD and TEM the size distribution of AgNPs were revealed around 20 nm in diameter and has narrow distribution of 50 nm. From the EDX analysis (Fig. 9), the distinct peak noticed at 3 keV confirmed the presence of elemental metal ions. The present result corroborates with Prasad et al., [62].

sections.heading: 3.4. Antimicrobial Studies of AgNPs
sections.text:
Seaweeds contains antioxidants, polysaccharides with antiviral activity and ω3 fatty acids which are excellent biological active components [59]. AgNPs may attach to the cell membrane disturbing permeability and respiration functions of the cell [65] which cause structural modification such leads cell death [66]. The other possibility is without interacting the cell membrane can also penetrate the bacteria [64,67].The biologically synthesized AgNPs shows excellent antibacterial activity against pathogens such as S. aureus, K. pneumonia, P. vulgaris and B. subtilis. The zone of inhibition in diameter for three replicates was recorded (Table 3).
The gram negative bacterium P. vulgaris shows the maximum zone of inhibition (13.8mm) because as the gram positive bacterial cell wall consists of linear polysaccharide chains linked with short peptides [68]. These leads more difficulties in penetration of AgNPs because of the peptidoglycon layer in cell wall than gram negative bacteria [69–72]. When comparing it to standard antibiotics action (Table 3) AgNPs showed good activity against the pathogens.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: TiO2-ZnO mixed metal oxide nanocomposite was synthesized using co-precipitation method with particle size of ~12 nm. The process parameters were optimized and higher yield of FAME of hydroxydecanoic acid conversion of 82.8% was obtained from U. lactuca. The solid biomass of U. lactuca after transesterification was effectively used for synthesis of AgNPs as it contains effective reducing and capping agents. The nanoparticles synthesized were spherical and ~24 nm in size, shows to be a promising material with higher antibacterial activity. The antibacterial activity was excellent against bacterial pathogens and treatment against P. vulgaris shows the maximum zone of inhibition (13.8mm). The biogenic AgNPs synthesized from U. lactuca extract can be applied as an ingredient in the potential antimicrobial drug formulation.

metadata.abstractText: TiO2-ZnO heterogeneous catalytic system provides a good replacement of a homogeneous catalytic reaction due to its easier recovery. In this study, biodiesel was produced from Ulva lactuca seaweeds using TiO2–ZnO nanocomposite catalysts with particle size of ~12 nm. The size controlled TiO2–ZnO nanocomposite was characterized by powder XRD analysis and TEM. The result of that TiO2–ZnO catalyst is a promising catalyst for the production of biodiesel under mild reaction conditions and high yield of hydroxydecanoic acid conversion of 82.8%. The various conditions optimized for the higher conversion to FAME (15.8ml of FAME) were 4 wt% catalysts at 4 h under 60 °C and further there is no increase of conversion to FAME above 60 °C–80 °C. The total product yield was calculated as 82.8% of conversion to FAME. The evaluated biodiesel was found to be up to the mark of ASTM standards. The silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) were synthesized by using leftover biomass of algae obtaining after lipid extraction of U.lactuca. AgNPs particle size was achieved as ~12 nm and was confirmed by UV–Visible spectroscopy, XRD and TEM analysis. Antibacterial activities of the synthesized AgNPs were analyzed and compared. The antibacterial activity was excellent against bacterial pathogens and treatment against P. vulgaris shows the maximum zone of inhibition (13.8mm). The present work identified that the unutilized bioresource such as U.lactuca can be effectively utilized for biodiesel production so as to replace fossil fuel usage.
